Speaker: baseball fan
Dialogue: I'll knock your block off, you big stiff ! You're a bum !

Speaker: the umpire
Dialogue: Strike ! You're out !

Speaker: the photographer
Dialogue: I wonder if any big shots are getting married today ? They stop at the door of the room.

Speaker: the photographer
Dialogue: Hey, the guy with the cheaters.

Speaker: the photographer
Dialogue: Mortimer Brewster, the dramatic critic ?

Speaker: the clerk
Dialogue: "Two by two they come and go. Hip hip hig hay !"

Speaker: the clerk
Dialogue: Good morning, children. Your name, please ?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Elaine Harper.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Elaine Harper.

Speaker: the clerk
Dialogue: Thank you. Yours ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Mortimer Brewster. The clerk puts his hand back around his ear.

Speaker: the clerk
Dialogue: How's that ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Mortimer Brewster.

Speaker: the clerk
Dialogue: Speak up, sonny. There's nothing to be afraid of.

Speaker: the clerk
Dialogue: Love her ? But of course you love her. You're going to marry her, aren't you ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: No-no, you don't understand. Come here, come.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: You see, I don't want this to get out for a while. I'm Mortimer Brewster.

Speaker: the clerk
Dialogue: You're who ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Mortimer Brew...

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Goodbye, dear.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Don't you understand ? How can I marry you ? Me, the symbol of bachelorhood. I've sneered at every love scene in every play. I've written four million words against marriage ! Not only hooked, but to a minister's daughter, and not only a minister's daughter but a girl from Brooklyn. And look at the way you look ! What is that sort of contraption you've got there ?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: That's a pin I borrowed from your aunts. You know what they're saying, "Something borrowed..."

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Yeah, I know that "Something borrowed, something blue." Old, new. Rice and old shoes. Carry you over the threshold. Niagara Falls. All that silly tripe I made fun for years. Is this what I've come to ? I can't go through with it. I won't marry you. And that's that.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Yes, Mortimer. MORTIMER What do you mean, Yes, Mortimer ? Aren't you insulted ? Aren't you going to cry ? Aren't you going to make a scene ?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: No, Mortimer.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: And don't No, Mortimer me, either ! Don't you see marriage is a superstition. It's old-fashioned. It's... a... a... Ohh !...

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: O'Hara, don't be a jerk. You don't seem to realize. I'm turning over to you the nicest, the best beat in Brooklyn. Now look at that old church. And them old houses. O'HARA Did George Washington ever do any sleeping around here ?

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Of course he did. Well, this whole neighborhood just stinks with atmosphere. And look at that old house there.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Now, don't crack wise about the Brewster sisters. They're two of the dearest, sweetest, kindest old ladies that ever walked the earth. They're out of this world. They're like... they're like pressed rose leaves. They have come near a police call box. Brophy takes a key out of his pocket to open the box

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: No, no. Their old man left them fixed for life. And don't you call them the girls, either.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Brophy. Is Lieutenant around ?

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: They don't rent rooms. But you can bet if anybody came looking for a room, they wouldn't go away without a good meal and probably a couple of bucks in their pockets. That's just their way of digging up people to do good to.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Reverend Harper, I do hope you don't disapprove of Mortimer just because he's a dramatic critic and takes your daughter to the theater every night.

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: It's not so much that I disapprove of his being a critic, but no man, no man with this published attitude on marriage...

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: ...at any time.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: I must be catching cold.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Bless you.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: We mustn't be angry with Mortimer. He's so very much in love with her. And Sister Martha and I are so happy about it. He used to come to see us only occasionally, and now, now he's in Brooklyn six nights a week.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Remember now, watch your language.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: You'd be surprised what they'd consider swearing.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, will you excuse me ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: No, no, Teddy, dear. Thank you. I'll go.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, come right in, Mr. Brophy.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Miss Abby, we came for the toys.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh yes.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: This is Officer O'Hara. He's taking over my beat.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: May I welcome you to our neighborhood, Mister O'Hara.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Gentlemen, what news have you brought me ?

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Colonel, we have nothing to report.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Splendid ! Thank you, gentlemen.  At ease.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: You know the Reverend Doctor Harper from the church next door ?

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Hello, Reverend. This is Officer O'Hara, the new man on the beat.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: The toys are on the chair up here, by the library door.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, Teddy, will you run upstairs and bring down your Army and Navy from Aunt Martha's room. They're all packed.

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: That's splendid work you men do, fixing up discarded toys for the kids at camp.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Charge !

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: It gives us something to do as we are sitting around the station. You get tired of playing cards.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: So these are the toys ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: How's Missis Brophy ?

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Oh, she's better, thank you. But a little weak, still.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Well, I'll better get some beef broth for you to take to her.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Oh, Miss Abby, please don't bother. You've done so much already.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, Stuff and nonsense ! I won't be a minute.

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: Gentlemen, if I know what pure kindness and absolute generosity are, it's because I've known the Brewster sisters.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Oh, Teddy, you promised me you wouldn't do that anymore.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: But I have to call a Cabinet meeting to get the release of those supplies.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Now don't do that again. Do you hear me ?

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: He used to do that in the middle of the night, and neighbors raised Cain with me. They're a little afraid of him anyway.

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: Oh, he's quite harmless.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: He thinks he's Teddy Roosevelt. So what, there's a lot of worse guys he could think he was.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Isn't it a shame, Father, isn't it a shame, Reverend, that a nice family like this should be hatching a cuckoo ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Oh, well, now, isn't this nice !

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Good afternoon, Miss Brewster.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: How do you do, Mr Brophy ?

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: Good afternoon, Miss Brewster. O'Hara has picked up the toys and he joins the group.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Reverend Harper, how do you do ?

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Oh, Miss Martha, this is Officer O'Hara. He's taking over my duties.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: I'm very glad to know you.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, Martha, you're back.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Here's the broth for Missis Brophy. Be sure it's good and hot.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: You bet I will, and thank you very much.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: The Army and Navy are ready for action.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Oh, Colonel, this is grand. It'll make a lot of kids happy.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: What's this ? The Oregon ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Oh, Teddy, dear, put it back.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: But the Oregon goes to Australia.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Now, Teddy...

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: No, it goes to Australia.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: These are lovely. Thank you very much.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Not at all.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: The children will go crazy.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, now, don't mention it.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Hey ?

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Oh, yes.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Dismissed !

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Well, goodbye and thank you. ABBY Good bye.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Careful of the step here now with the toys.

Speaker: brophy
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Young man, let that be a lesson to you.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Goodbye. She closes the door, and goes back to her sister and Reverend Harper.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Well...

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: Well, I must be going.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Charge !

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Charge the blockhouse !

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: Blockhouse ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Oh, the stairs are always San Juan Hill.

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: Oh, I...

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Bless you !

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: Have you ever tried to persuade him he wasn't Teddy Roosevelt ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, no !

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Oh, he's so happy being Teddy Roosevelt.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, do you remember, Martha ? She comes back to her sister and Reverend Harper.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Once, a long time ago, we thought if he'd be George Washington, it might be a change for him, and we suggested it.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: And do you know what happened ? He just stayed under his bed for days and wouldn't be anybody.

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: Well, if he's happy, and what's more important, you're happy...

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Oh, our only worry for Teddy is after we are gone.

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: Yes, indeed. That is quite a problem.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: But Mortimer's made all the arrangements for Teddy to go to Happy Dale Sanitarium after we pass on.

Speaker: reverend harper
Dialogue: Splendid idea ! A very pleasant place.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Yes...

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Dear, sweet Reverend Harper.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: You know, Martha, I really do believe he's beginning to see the light.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: I'm sure we needn't worry about him. He won't interfere with our plans for Mortimer and Elaine.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Oh, did you just have tea ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Yes. And dinner's going to be late, too.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Ohh ! Why ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Teddy ?...

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, Teddy, good news for you. You're going to Panama and dig another lock for the canal.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Delighted !

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: That's bully ! Just bully ! I shall prepare at once for the journey. He starts mounting the stairs, stops and goes back a few steps down, takes his imaginary sword out, points it forward, and runs upstairs, yelling :

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Charge !

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Abby ! While I was out ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Yes, dear. I just couldn't wait for you. I didn't know when you'd be back, and Reverend Harper was coming.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: But all by yourself.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, I got along fine.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: I'll run right downstairs and see.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: No, no, dear. There wasn't time. And I was all alone.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Well ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Martha, just look in the window-seat.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh ! It's Elaine !

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: You, darlings.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: But, Elaine ! ABBY What did she mean ? You don't suppose they've gone and...

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Elaine !

Speaker: cab driver
Dialogue: Listen, buddy. This old cab has seen osculation but...

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: You ain't seen anything yet. You've got to drive us to the station.

Speaker: cab driver
Dialogue: You'd better take her hat.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Oh thanks.

Speaker: cab driver
Dialogue: Wait a minute. Wait a minute. Wait a... And her brooch.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: If you find her hairpins, you can keep them. Hold on to that.

Speaker: cab driver
Dialogue: Yeah ! Mortimer runs across the churchyard to meet Elaine.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: There they are.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Here's your hat.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Just throw it. I don't like that look in your eyes.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: What ? What's the matter ?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Father preached in sermon about it only last Sunday. MORTIMER He did ? He did ? What did he say ? What did he say ?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: He was against it.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Ah ! But that was only Sunday.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Please ! For heaven's sake !

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: But, Mortimer, right out here in the open with everyone looking ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Yeah ! Right out here in the open with everyone looking. Let everyone in Brooklyn over 16 look.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: One thing at a time.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Oh ! There's that look again !

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: There's that look again, Mortimer ! You better get used to it.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Look like you're going to see it often. It goes just before this. He kisses her very passionately.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: You know what we're doing, darling ? We're wasting time. Look, I'll go tell my aunts and you tell your old... No, you'd better not tell your father just yet. You'll run that cold of his into a pneumonia.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Oh, I can handle Father. He's a dear.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Look, why don't we wire him from Niagara Falls ?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Niagara Falls ?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Then that's why you stopped at your office.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Yes, certainly ! We're going to go the whole hog. Niagara Falls ! Everybody ought to go to Niagara Falls. You should've seen my secretary's face when I made the reservation. We've got a drawing-room on the train, the bridal suite in the hotel, and tomorrow morning we go over the falls in a barrel.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Go on, darling, hurry and pack.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I don't have to. I started packing the day after I met you. She starts moving away. He holds her back.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: There, you see ! You see ? That's what I mean. That's what I hate about women.

Speaker: cab driver
Dialogue: I wonder what Mary's doing now ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Go on, darling, the train leaves in an hour, and hurry.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: It'll be a few minutes before I'm ready. Father may want to pray over me a little.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Whistle when you're ready. Oh, Elaine...

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: When you whistle, open the front door fast. If you see a tall, dark streak of light, it's me.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: What ? Now ?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: No, not now !

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Aunt Abby, Aunt Martha !

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Hold on to your bustles. We're married. Elaine and I are married.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, darling, how wonderful ! Oh, Martha, isn't it wonderful ? They're married!

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Yeah ! Don't pretend to be so surprised either, you two old frauds. Can I use the telephone, darling ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Yes, of course.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Isn't it too, too wonderful ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: And to think that it happened right here in this room !

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Oh, now, here, here, now ! Hello ?... Hello ? Benson's Florists ? This is Mortimer Brewster. Did you send those roses to Missis Brewster's apartment ?... You did ? Good. Now, send four dozen more to drawing room A, Canadian Limited, Grand Central Station. Yes... And hurry then. And throw in a flock of orange blossoms.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: But before you go, we can have our celebration. I'll open a bottle of wine and we'll sing. And we'll invite a few of the neighbors in.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: And, of course, a wedding cake. MORTIMER Oh, darling, you won't have time to bake a cake. We're going to Niagara Falls. I've got a taxi waiting.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, it's all ready. It's been ready since..

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Yeah, I bet it's been ready since the first day I met her, huh ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: What is it ? Did everybody in Brooklyn know I was getting married, except me ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Oh, we knew you'd find out about it in time.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Well, I'll run along and get everything ready.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, dear. I do hope the Reverend isn't too angry. You know how your books upset him.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Well, I'm going to burn all my books. And I'll let the Reverend Harper light the first match. Oh, by the way, did I leave some notes here for my new book ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: You mean Mind Over Matrimony ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Yes ! Shhh ! Where are they ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: I hid them someplace...

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Come on, come on. Let's go.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Now you behave. She goes away on her search.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Let's find them before Elaine sees them.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Hello, Mortimer !

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: How are you, Mister President ?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Bully, thank you. Just bully. What news have you brought me ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Just this, Mister President. The country's squarely behind you.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Yes, I know. Isn't it wonderful ?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Well, goodbye. I'm off to Panama.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Goodbye, Mister President.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: A new lock for the canal, you know.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Oh, tell the news to Mother.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, dear.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Did you find those notes ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: What's the matter ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: There's a baby picture of your brother Jonathan.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: You ought to put that in the fire with my books. My, what a face !

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: I remember now. He used to scare grownups with it.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Just the thought of Jonathan frightens me. Do you remember how he used to cut worms in two with his teeth ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Oh, Jonathan ? Oh, he's probably in prison or hanged or something by now.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: I saw a play, which had a character in it. Reminded me of Jonathan.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: No ? Really?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Yeah. Oh, a honey of a lunatic. One of those whodunits called Murder Will Out.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, dear ! Abby goes into the kitchen.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Yeah, what a play. When the curtain goes up, the first thing you see is a dead body.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: The next thing...

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Hey, mister. He remains a few seconds seated of the seat, with a very puzzled face.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Happy bridegroom !

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Congratulations, darling !

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Never mind that now. I know.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Now, listen, darlings. Aunt Abby, Aunt Martha, you know how we've always planned to send Teddy to that Sanitarium, Happy Dale ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, yes, dear. That's after we're gone.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Yes, we talked with Reverend Harper about it.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: No, no. Teddy's got to go to Happy Dale now. At once ! Now, he's down in the cellar. Get him up here right away.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: But, there's no such hurry as yet, you know.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: No... When Teddy's working on the canal, you can't get his mind on anything else.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Well, look, darlings. Look, I'm frightfully sorry, but I've got an awful shock for you.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Teddy's killed a man, darlings !

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Nonsense !

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: But there's a body in the window-seat !

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Yes, dear. We know.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: You know ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Yes, but it has nothing to do with Teddy.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Now, Mortimer. You just forget about it. Forget you ever saw the gentleman. MORTIMER Forget ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: We never dreamed you'd peek.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: What the... Who is he ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: He's a Mister Hoskins. Adam Hoskins. That's really all I know about him, except that he's a Methodist.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Oh ! He's a Methodist ? Isn't that nice.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: That's all you know ? But what's he doing here ? What happened to him ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Look, Aunt Martha, men just don't get into window-seats and die.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: No, dear. He died first.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Oh, well, now wait ! Stop all this.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Now look, darlings, how did he die ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, Mortimer, don't be so inquisitive. The gentleman died because he drank some wine with poison in it.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: But, how did the poison get in the wine ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Well we put it in wine because it's less noticeable. When it's in tea, it has a distinct odor.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: You mean you...  You put it in the wine ? ABBY Yes. And I put Mister Hoskins in the window-seat, because Reverend Harper was coming.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Ohh ! Look at me, darling.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: You mean, you mean you knew what you'd done and you didn't want the Reverend Harper to see the body ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Well, not at tea. That wouldn't have been very nice.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Ohh ! It's first-degree.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Now, Mortimer, you know all about it and just forget about it. I do think that Martha and I have the right to our own little secrets.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Oh, Abby, while I was out I dropped in on Missis Schultz. She's much better. But she wants us to take Junior to the movies again.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Well, we must do that, tomorrow or next day.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Yes, but this time we'll go where we want to go. Junior's not going to drag me into another one of those scary pictures.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: No, they ought not to be allowed to make those pictures just to frighten people.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Operator ?... Can you hear my voice ?... You can ?... Are you sure ?...

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, the dears. Isn't Halloween a wonderful time for them ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Yes, it is. They have so much fun.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Now, Mortimer, don't be so impatient. We'll let you lick the bowl out.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Lick the bowl ? I don't want to lick the bowl. I want to know what we're going to do !

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Well, we're going to celebrate, dear.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Celebrate ? There's a body in the window-seat !

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Yes, dear. Mister Hoskins.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Oh, I know what his name is. I just want to know what we're going to do. We can't turn you over to the police.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Yes. You just should get stop worrying about it.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: We told you to forget the whole thing.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Forget ? Look, my dear aunt Martha, can't I make you realize that something has to be done ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Now, Mortimer, you behave. You're too old to be flying off the handle like this. MORTIMER But, but Mister Hodgekiss...

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Hoskins, dear.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: But whatever his name is, you can't leave him in there.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: We don't intend to, dear.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: No, Teddy's down in the cellar now, digging the lock.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Oh, you mean you're going to bury Mister Hodgekiss in the cellar ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Oh, yes, dear. That's what we did with the others.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Look, here, Aunt Martha. You can't...

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Others ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: The other gentlemen.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Oh ! When you say others, do you mean others ? More than one others ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Oh, yes, dear. Let me see now. This is eleven, isn't it, Abby ?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh no, dear. This makes twelve.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Abby, dear, I think you're wrong. This one is only eleven.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: No, dear, because I remember when Mister Hoskins first came in, it occurred to me that he'd make just an even dozen.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: But, look, Abby dear, I really don't think you should count the first one.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Oh, I was counting the first one, and that makes it twelve.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: It does ?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Well, she's probably right. Abby usually is. I get them mixed up sometimes.

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Makes it twelve. Well...

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Hello ?

Speaker: mortimer
Dialogue: Oh !

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Well, whatever is the matter with Mortimer today ?

Speaker: martha
